title: 52 Best Classic Passover Recipes - Easy Seder Meal Ideas
body: <style type="text/css">#sidepanel{transform:translateX(0);visibility:visible;content-visibility:auto;}@media (max-width:425px){#sidepanel{width:7rem;max-width:7rem;}#sidepanel .nav-item,#sidepanel .nav-item a,#sidepanel footer a,#sidepanel div a,#sidepanel a span{font-size:10px;}#sidepanel ul,#sidepanel div{padding:0;margin:0;}#sidepanel button{display:none;}}</style>SearchMy RecipesSubscribeMembership BenefitsRecipesMealsHolidaysFood TrendsNewsKitchen Tips & ToolsAll VideosAbout UsNewsletterDelish ShopFollowOther EditionsYour Privacy ChoicesPrivacy NoticeTerms Of UseSkip to ContentRecipesDinnersSpring RecipesKitchen TipsNewsSubscribesign inSearchLemon Blueberry DessertsSpring SaladsCopycat Recipe IdeasBrunch RecipesSpring DinnersMeals & CookingRecipe Headquarters52 Modern Passover Recipes To Spice Up Your Meals All Week Long52 Modern Passover Recipes To Spice Up Your Meals All Week Long"Chag Pesach Sameach!" or "Happy Passover!"By Camille LowderUpdated: Apr 2, 2025Save ArticlePHOTO: LINDA PUGLIESE; FOOD STYLING: TAYLOR ANN SPENCERNo matter if you're new to the springtime Jewish holiday or have been celebrating your whole life, you'll quickly learn that Passover (April 12 to 20, 2025) often involves some long-established menu items you must have at your Seder dinner table. Chances are, there's a few things you are likely going to be eating all week long (hi, hello matzo), but for everything else, it‚Äôs a real mix of what you or your family and loved ones are into. Our 52 Passover dinner recipes includes both classics and innovative recipes so you can truly make the holiday your own.The term ‚ÄúPassover‚Äù refers to the biblical stories of the 10 plagues sent by God to convince the Egyptian pharaoh to ‚Äúlet the Jewish people go‚Äù and the eventual exodus of the Jewish people from Egypt. The last of the 10 plagues was the killing of all firstborn Egyptian sons, during which God instructed the Jewish people to slaughter a lamb and mark their doorposts with its blood to instruct the Angel of Death to ‚Äúpass over‚Äù them. After this last plague, the Pharaoh ordered the Jews to leave Egypt. As the story goes, they packed in such a hurry that they didn‚Äôt have enough time to even let their bread rise (if you‚Äôve ever made homemade bread, you can imagine), and only were able to bring unleavened, cracker-like bread called matzo with them. To celebrate this exodus, Jewish people today continue to remove chametz from their diets (and their homes, for some strict households) for the duration of Passover, as well as make sure all other ingredients they‚Äôre using are specified Kosher for Passover. Simply put, chametz is basically any leavened flour product like bread, cake, cookies, etc. Traditionally Jewish people also have avoided kitniyot, or legumes (like peanuts, peas, and beans), though recently modern families have begun reintroducing them into their Passover diets. In addition, they must continue to follow general Kosher rules (meat and dairy can‚Äôt be eaten in the same meal, though fish and eggs are considered neutral, or pareve; no pork products; etc.) Most families also traditionally make a seder plate full of items that help in the retelling of the Passover story before dinner.We get it, this might all seem like a LOT. We‚Äôll assume that if you‚Äôre keeping strictly kosher, you‚Äôll be aware of Kosher products and the regulations you abide by, and will sub in or out of these recipes as needed. For everyone else, we hope these recipes will help broaden your perspective, and inspire you to try something new. We think the best part about appreciating a culture you‚Äôre not a part of is the opportunity to try something new, while also having the flexibility to (respectfully!) not be perfect about it.No matter what, it‚Äôs a great time to avoid processed foods, and you‚Äôll largely find only whole ingredients here. We‚Äôve got options for a seder plate, like homemade charoset (and an egg salad to use up your hard-boiled eggs), as well as many noodle-less, low-carb ‚Äúpasta‚Äù alternatives. Hot tips: make your noodles out of eggs, and turn your matzo into a pastrami-inspired kugel or pizza! A brisket is classic, but we‚Äôve included some other impressive roast meats, like chicken, rack of lamb, and salmon too. Side dishes‚Äîlike our cranberry apple quinoa salad, our potato kugel, and chicken matzo ball soup‚Äîare also represented. End your meal with a creative twist on matzo, like in our matzo icebox cake or our chocolate matzo toffee (we‚Äôve got coconut macaroons, pavlova cupcakes, and a flourless chocolate coconut cake too if you‚Äôre SO over matzo by then üòú).For more Passover inspiration, click here to see how Miayim Bialik gets ready for her (vegan) seder dinner, and here for more Slightly Kosher recipes. 1Pastrami Matzo KugelPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: BROOKE CAISONOf all the various kugels (potato and noodle being the most popular), matzo kugel tends to not get any love. This incredibly flavorful Reuben-inspired recipe is here to change all that.Get the Pastrami Matzo Kugel recipe.2Matzo Ball SoupPHOTO: JOSEPH DE LEO; FOOD STYLING: MAKINZE GOREA symbolic dish of past hardships, warming matzo ball soup is an essential component of the Passover feast. The time and effort you invest really pays off here; plus, it couldn‚Äôt be easier. Throw a few roughly chopped vegetables, a whole chicken or two, some herbs, and chicken stock into a large pot and basically walk away for two hours.Get the Matzo Ball Soup recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below3Apple Cider Braised BrisketPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: BROOKE CAISONApple cider adds a subtle sweetness to a classic brisket, and after letting it braise low and slow, it will be as tender as possible. Letting the potatoes and carrots cook with the brisket flavors them from the inside out, and the whole dish will be deeply savory. Get the Apple Cider Braised Brisket recipe. 4Pavlova Cupcakes With Raspberry SaucePHOTO: ANDREW BUI; FOOD STYLING: MAKINZE GOREPavlovas have a crispy exterior with a soft, marshmallow-like interior, and these mini ones made into cupcakes are ideal for serving to guests. Dollop with a little homemade whipped cream and raspberry sauce for the perfect bite.Get the Pavlova Cupcakes With Raspberry Sauce recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below5Sweet & Sour Braised Red CabbagePHOTO: JOEL GOLDBERG; FOOD STYLING: HADLEY SUIOne of our favorite ways to prepare cabbage is to braise it. This mostly hands-off method produces perfectly crisp-tender cabbage, with a TON of flavor.Get the Sweet & Sour Braised Red Cabbage recipe.6Matzo Fried FishPHOTO: LINDA PUGLIESE; FOOD STYLING: TAYLOR ANN SPENCERMatzo might often be destined for matzo balls, matzo brei, and chocolate toffee bark, but its potential doesn‚Äôt end there. Now we‚Äôre transforming this Passover staple into a crispy golden brown coating for pan-fried fish, which, paired with a light, crunchy cabbage slaw, will soon become a favorite in your household year-round.Get the Matzo Fried Fish recipe. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below7Hot Honey Chicken & Brussels SproutsPHOTO: DOAA ELKADY; FOOD STYLING: TAYLOR ANN SPENCERLooking to spice up your usual Passover main? Make hot honey chicken and Brussels sprouts. Featuring a simple glaze hacked from a store-bought condiment, this one-skillet meal promises maximum flavor with minimal fuss, and tender chicken with gorgeous golden-brown, shatteringly crispy skin.Get the Hot Honey Chicken & Brussels Sprouts recipe.8Matzo Magic BarsPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: SPENCER RICHARDSIf you've ever had magic bars (aka seven-layer bars), you know a great dessert doesn't have to be complicated. These matzo-based bars are a genius play on the no-fuss sweet √† la cookbook author Molly Yeh, and they're the perfect Passover dessert when you don't have time to make coconut macaroons.Get the Matzo Magic Bars recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below9Matzo PizzaPHOTO: ANDREW BUI; FOOD STYLING: SPENCER RICHARDSWhether you observe Passover and have leftover matzo to use up or are just looking for a crispy, crunchy, thin-crust pizza, this recipe is going to be a hit. Use this recipe as a guide to whatever flavor combinations you can think of!Get the Matzo Pizza recipe.10Cranberry Apple Quinoa SaladPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: BARRETT WASHBURNEWe don‚Äôt believe in boring salads at Delish, and crunchy apples and tart cranberries bring a lot of life to this one. The slightly sweet and lemony dressing is a delight, so make extra and put it on everything during Passover.Get the Cranberry Apple Quinoa Salad recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below11Steamed Carrots With Hot Honey ButterPHOTO: JOEL GOLDBERG; FOOD STYLING: LENA ABRAHAMTo make this delicious vegetarian side dish, you'll toss a pound of steamed carrots in a slightly spicy honey-butter glaze. Rather than cooking the carrots and the glaze together in the pan, you'll cook the carrots and the glaze separately. Serve these as part of a spring brunch spread or alongside roasted lamb at Passover. Get the Steamed Carrots With Hot Honey Butter recipe. 12One-Pan Coconut-Lime ChickenPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: MAKINZE GOREWe paired quick-cooking chicken cutlets with a spicy-sweet coconut milk sauce that‚Äôs out-of-this-world tasty. Tomatoes (and tomato paste) bring it back down to Earth, so you can make this over and over (and over!) again this Passover. Not convinced? Did we mention this comes together in just one pan, in less than 30 minutes?!Get the One-Pan Coconut-Lime Chicken recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below13Roast ChickenPHOTO: ROCKY LUTEN; FOOD STYLING: BROOKE CAISONThe perfect roast chicken recipe doesn't require a lot of extra ingredients, just some kosher salt and freshly ground pepper. Really! That's it. The steps to make this chicken are simple, too: You season the bird, then roast it at high heat until the skin is bronzed and crisp and the flesh juicy. The perfect centerpiece to your Passover dinner, this roast chicken recipe is an absolute must to have up your sleeve. Get the Roast Chicken recipe. 14Air Fryer Coconut MacaroonsPHOTO: JOEL GOLDBERG; FOOD STYLING: HADLEY SUIThese are the perfect bite-size treat for any time of day‚Äîfeel free to skip the chocolate if you want to keep them less sweet. For a pink, raspberry version, smash 1/4 cup fresh raspberries into the foamy egg white mixture with a fork and then toss in the coconut.Get the Air Fryer Coconut Macaroons recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below15Feta & Herb-Crusted SalmonPHOTO: LUCY SCHAEFFER; FOOD STYLING: TAYLOR ANN SPENCERFor this Mediterranean-inspired dish, you just arrange your salmon on a sheet tray (lined with aluminum foil for the easiest cleanup), sprinkle on the toppings, and bake it for 25 minutes. No flipping, no sticking, and no mess!Get the Feta & Herb Crusted Salmon recipe.16Rack Of LambPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: MAKINZE GOREA roasted rack of lamb is the perfect Passover showstopper. Don't forget to make this with enough time to spare‚Äîas with other meats, you'll want to let it rest before carving to ensure that all the juices stay locked in.Get the Rack of Lamb recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below17House Latkes With HorseradishPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: ERIKA JOYCEThough latkes are commonly served with applesauce and plain sour cream, here, they get a flavor-boost with a spicy horseradish and chive sour cream topping, which adds savory depth to each bite.Get the House Latkes With Horseradish recipe.18Feta, Spinach, & Tomato Stuffed SalmonPHOTO: ERIK BERNSTEIN; FOOD STYLING: BROOKE CAISONWe're always on the hunt for Passover dinner ideas that can do double-duty as a casual dinner wonder and a seder party stunner, and this stuffed salmon does just that. Oven-roasted salmon is already delicious on its own, but adding a filling made of briny feta cheese, earthy cooked spinach, and savory-sweet cherry tomatoes will take your favorite fish up a few notches.Get the Feta, Spinach, & Tomato Stuffed Salmon recipe.Advertisement - Continue Reading Below19Chicken MarbellaThe most signature part of this dish has to be the complex, sweet-briny marinade that flavors our chicken. With prunes, olives, capers, and herbs, this marinade might seem surprising, but trust us‚Äîthe result is a flavor-packed dish you won't be able to get enough of.Get the Chicken Marbella recipe.20Best Chicken SaladANDREW BUIWe'd argue that our balance of add-ins here is the pinnacle, but once you nail the chicken and the dressing, you can feel free to spread your wings and give it your own personal flair.Get the Best Chicken Salad recipe.Watch Next¬†Advertisement - Continue Reading BelowBEST PASSOVER EVER!Matzo Icebox CakeMatzo Ball Soup Matzo BreiCharosetAdvertisement - Continue Reading BelowTzimmes47 Flourless Passover DessertsMatzo Fried FishBeef BrisketPastrami Matzo Kugel27 Vegetarian & Kosher Passover Recipes26 Perfect Passover Chicken Recipes16 Passover-Friendly Cookie RecipesAdvertisement - Continue Reading BelowNewsletterSubscribeManage SubscriptionAbout UsDelish Test KitchenMedia KitCommunity GuidelinesAdvertise With UsDelish Shop Product SupportOther Hearst SubscriptionsDelish Unlimited Membership SupportTurn off Web NotificationsA Part of Hearst Digital MediaWe may earn commission from links on this page, but we only recommend products we back.¬©2025 Hearst Magazine Media, Inc. target=\"_blank\"\u003ePassover\u003c/a\u003e (April 12 to 20, 2025) often involves some long-established menu items you must have at your \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/holiday-recipes/a43452846/passover-seder-plate/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSeder dinner table\u003c/a\u003e. Chances are, there's a few things you are likely going to be eating all week long (hi, hello \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/menus/g2662/passover-matzah-recipes/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ematzo\u003c/a\u003e), but for everything else, it‚Äôs a real mix of what you or your family and loved ones are into. Our 52 Passover dinner recipes includes both classics and innovative recipes so you can truly make the holiday your own.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe term ‚ÄúPassover‚Äù refers to the biblical stories of the 10 plagues sent by God to convince the Egyptian pharaoh to ‚Äúlet the Jewish people go‚Äù and the eventual exodus of the Jewish people from Egypt. The last of the 10 plagues was the killing of all firstborn Egyptian sons, during which God instructed the Jewish people to slaughter a lamb and mark their doorposts with its blood to instruct the Angel of Death to ‚Äúpass over‚Äù them. After this last plague, the Pharaoh ordered the Jews to leave Egypt. As the story goes, they packed in such a hurry that they didn‚Äôt have enough time to even let their bread rise (if you‚Äôve ever made homemade \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a25810151/how-to-make-sourdough-bread-recipe/\"\u003ebread\u003c/a\u003e, you can imagine), and only were able to bring unleavened, cracker-like bread called matzo with them. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo celebrate this exodus, Jewish people today continue to remove \u003cem\u003echametz\u003c/em\u003e from their diets (and their homes, for some strict households) for the duration of Passover, as well as make sure all other ingredients they‚Äôre using are specified Kosher for Passover. Simply put, \u003cem\u003echametz\u003c/em\u003e is basically any leavened flour product like \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/g32055235/best-bread-recipes/\"\u003ebread\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/g22/spring-cakes-cupcakes-recipes/\"\u003ecake\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/g1956/best-cookies/\"\u003ecookies\u003c/a\u003e, etc. Traditionally Jewish people also have avoided \u003cem\u003ekitniyot\u003c/em\u003e, or \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a31982706/how-to-cook-beans/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003elegumes\u003c/a\u003e (like \u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003epeanuts, peas, and beans), though recently modern families have begun reintroducing them into their Passover diets. In addition, they must continue to follow general Kosher rules (meat and dairy can‚Äôt be eaten in the same meal, though fish and eggs are considered neutral, or pareve; no pork products; etc.) Most families also traditionally make a \u003cem\u003eseder\u003c/em\u003e plate full of items that help in the retelling of the Passover story before dinner.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWe get it, this might all seem like a LOT. We‚Äôll assume that if you‚Äôre keeping strictly kosher, you‚Äôll be aware of Kosher products and the regulations you abide by, and will sub in or out of these recipes as needed. For everyone else, we hope these recipes will help broaden your perspective, and inspire you to try something new. We think the best part about appreciating a culture you‚Äôre not a part of is the opportunity to try something new, while also having the flexibility to (respectfully!) not be perfect about it.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eNo matter what, it‚Äôs a great time to avoid processed foods, and you‚Äôll largely find only whole ingredients here. We‚Äôve got options for a seder plate, like homemade \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a31790190/charoset-recipe/\"\u003echaroset\u003c/a\u003e (and an \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/recipes/a51871/egg-salad-recipe/\"\u003eegg salad\u003c/a\u003e to use up your hard-boiled eggs), as well as many noodle-less, \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/g25909637/low-carb-pasta/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003elow-carb ‚Äúpasta‚Äù\u003c/a\u003e alternatives. Hot tips: make your \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/nutrition/a28366266/cacio-e-pepe-egg-noodles-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003enoodles out of eggs\u003c/a\u003e, and turn your matzo into a \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a42864625/pastrami-matzo-kugel-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epastrami-inspired kugel\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a43063742/matzo-pizza-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epizza\u003c/a\u003e! A \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a19473587/best-beef-brisket-recipe/\"\u003ebrisket\u003c/a\u003e is classic, but we‚Äôve included some other impressive roast meats, like \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/holiday-recipes/g27103780/passover-chicken-recipes/\"\u003echicken\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/recipes/a58701/best-rack-of-lamb-recipe/\"\u003erack of lamb\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/g2039/salmon-recipes/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esalmon\u003c/a\u003e too. \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/holiday-recipes/g42673764/passover-side-dishes/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSide dishes\u003c/a\u003e‚Äîlike our \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a42028408/cranberry-apple-quinoa-salad-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ecranberry apple quinoa salad\u003c/a\u003e, our \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a27133114/best-potato-kugel-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epotato kugel\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a19473716/best-chicken-matzo-ball-soup-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003echicken matzo ball soup\u003c/a\u003e‚Äîare also represented. End your meal with a creative twist on matzo, like in our \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/recipes/a52352/matzoh-icebox-cake/\"\u003ematzo icebox cake\u003c/a\u003e or our \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a35842964/chocolate-toffee-matzo-recipe/\"\u003echocolate matzo toffee\u003c/a\u003e (we‚Äôve got \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/recipes/a52234/ultimate-macaroons-recipe/\"\u003ecoconut macaroons\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a43222124/pavlova-cupcakes-recipe/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epavlova cupcakes\u003c/a\u003e, and a \u003ca href=\"https://www.delish.com/cooking/recipe-ideas/a39498963/flourless-chocolate-coconut-cake-recipe/\"\u003eflourless chocolate coconut cake\u003c/a\u003e too if you‚Äôre SO over matzo by then üòú).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor more Passover inspiration, click \u003ca href=\"https://es-la.facebook.com/delish/videos/how-mayim-bialik-gets-ready-for-passover/10155291219722437/\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e to see how Miayim Bialik gets ready for her (vegan) \u003cem\u003eseder\u003c/em\u003e dinner, and \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQGGrzFoybiNF1RrmND9jxk9vqMAyp4sn\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e for more \u003cem\u003eSlightly Kosher\u003c/em\u003e recipes. \u003c/p\u003e","social_title":"52 Modern Passover Recipes To Spice Up Your Meals All Week Long","seo_meta_description":"Our list of Passover dinner recipe ideas includes both classics and innovative recipes so you can truly make the holiday your own this year. new to the springtime Jewish holiday or have been celebrating your whole life, you'll quickly learn that Passover (April 12 to 20, 2025) often involves some long-established menu items you must have at your Seder dinner table. Chances are, there's a few things you are likely going to be eating all week long (hi, hello matzo), but for everything else, it‚Äôs a real mix of what you or your family and loved ones are into. Our 52 Passover dinner recipes includes both classics and innovative recipes so you can truly make the holiday your own.The term ‚ÄúPassover‚Äù refers to the biblical stories of the 10 plagues sent by God to convince the Egyptian pharaoh to ‚Äúlet the Jewish people go‚Äù and the eventual exodus of the Jewish people from Egypt. The last of the 10 plagues was the killing of all firstborn Egyptian sons, during which God instructed the Jewish people to slaughter a lamb and mark their doorposts with its blood to instruct the Angel of Death to ‚Äúpass over‚Äù them. After this last plague, the Pharaoh ordered the Jews to leave Egypt. As the story goes, they packed in such a hurry that they didn‚Äôt have enough time to even let their bread rise (if you‚Äôve ever made homemade bread, you can imagine), and only were able to bring unleavened, cracker-like bread called matzo with them. To celebrate this exodus, Jewish people today continue to remove chametz from their diets (and their homes, for some strict households) for the duration of Passover, as well as make sure all other ingredients they‚Äôre using are specified Kosher for Passover. Simply put, chametz is basically any leavened flour product like bread, cake, cookies, etc. Traditionally Jewish people also have avoided kitniyot, or legumes (like peanuts, peas, and beans), though recently modern families have begun reintroducing them into their Passover diets. In addition, they must continue to follow general Kosher rules (meat and dairy can‚Äôt be eaten in the same meal, though fish and eggs are considered neutral, or pareve; no pork products; etc.) Most families also traditionally make a seder plate full of items that help in the retelling of the Passover story before dinner.We get it, this might all seem like a LOT. We‚Äôll assume that if you‚Äôre keeping strictly kosher, you‚Äôll be aware of Kosher products and the regulations you abide by, and will sub in or out of these recipes as needed. For everyone else, we hope these recipes will help broaden your perspective, and inspire you to try something new. We think the best part about appreciating a culture you‚Äôre not a part of is the opportunity to try something new, while also having the flexibility to (respectfully!) not be perfect about it.No matter what, it‚Äôs a great time to avoid processed foods, and you‚Äôll largely find only whole ingredients here. We‚Äôve got options for a seder plate, like homemade charoset (and an egg salad to use up your hard-boiled eggs), as well as many noodle-less, low-carb ‚Äúpasta‚Äù alternatives. Hot tips: make your noodles out of eggs, and turn your matzo into a pastrami-inspired kugel or pizza! A brisket is classic, but we‚Äôve included some other impressive roast meats, like chicken, rack of lamb, and salmon too. Side dishes‚Äîlike our cranberry apple quinoa salad, our potato kugel, and chicken matzo ball soup‚Äîare also represented. End your meal with a creative twist on matzo, like in our matzo icebox cake or our chocolate matzo toffee (we‚Äôve got coconut macaroons, pavlova cupcakes, and a flourless chocolate coconut cake too if you‚Äôre SO over matzo by then üòú).For more Passover inspiration, click here to see how Miayim Bialik gets ready for her (vegan) seder dinner, and here for more Slightly Kosher recipes.
